importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the lawsuit filing, indicating the current political conflict over congressional seating and constitutional authority.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from late September to October 21, 2025, when Grijalva won the election and the House delay began, highlighting the timeline of the conflict.

keyTakeAways: Arizona’s attorney general has filed a lawsuit against the U.S. House of Representatives over Speaker Mike Johnson’s refusal to administer the oath of office to newly elected Democrat Adelita Grijalva.
The lawsuit asserts that the Constitution requires elected representatives to be sworn in upon meeting qualification standards, regardless of Speaker’s discretion.
Johnson claims he is following Nancy Pelosi’s precedent of delaying swearing-in after recess, but the lawsuit argues this violates constitutional principles and is politically motivated.
The delay is accused of being a tactic to prevent a petition on Jeffrey Epstein records and to gain leverage in budget negotiations.
Grijalva, who won her election in late September, has not spoken to Johnson and is attempting to meet with him to resolve the dispute.
The Arizona attorney general argues that Johnson has no legal or practical impediment to swearing in Grijalva and that the delay harms both the congresswoman and Arizona’s representation.
The lawsuit seeks a court order allowing a qualified third party to administer the oath if Johnson refuses.

namedEntities.name: Adelita Grijalva
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A newly elected Democratic member of Congress from Arizona
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the central figure in the dispute over whether she can be sworn in due to Speaker Mike Johnson’s refusal, directly challenging the power of the Speaker to delay seating elected officials.

namedEntities.name: Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Republican Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the central authority figure refusing to administer the oath to Grijalva, citing precedent and political strategy, placing him at the center of the constitutional and political debate.

namedEntities.name: Kris Mayes
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is leading the state’s legal action to enforce the constitutional requirement of seating elected officials, representing a state-level response to federal governance issues.

namedEntities.name: Nancy Pelosi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former Republican Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her historical precedent is cited by Johnson as justification for delaying swearing-in, making her a reference point in the constitutional argument about Speaker authority.

namedEntities.name: Jeffrey Epstein
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Controversial figure associated with human trafficking and financial dealings
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The petition to release records related to Epstein is cited as a political motive for Johnson’s delay, suggesting the delay is a strategic move to avoid legislative action on sensitive topics.

namedEntities.name: U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the institution where the refusal to seat Grijalva occurs, and the legal action is filed against it, highlighting a constitutional dispute within the federal legislative system.

namedEntities.name: Arizona
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The state is directly involved through its attorney general filing a lawsuit, asserting that the delay undermines state representation and democratic accountability.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Arizona’s attorney general, Kris Mayes, has sued the U.S. House of Representatives over Republican Speaker Mike Johnson’s refusal to swear in newly elected Democratic congresswoman Adelita Grijalva, who won her seat in late September. The lawsuit argues that the Constitution requires all duly elected members to be sworn in, and that the Speaker has no constitutional authority to delay seating. Johnson claims he is following Nancy Pelosi’s precedent of delaying swearing-in after recess, but the lawsuit alleges this is a politically motivated tactic to avoid a petition on Jeffrey Epstein records and to strengthen his position in budget negotiations. The case underscores a constitutional debate over the power of the Speaker to control the swearing-in process and raises concerns about democratic representation and accountability. Grijalva, who has not yet spoken to Johnson, is seeking a direct meeting to resolve the issue, while the lawsuit seeks a court order allowing a qualified third party to administer the oath if Johnson refuses.
title: Arizona Sues Over Mike Johnson’s Refusal to Swear In Democrats’ Newest Congresswoman
